### [ How Will Walgreens’ Expansion Into Specialty Pharmacy Affect The Industry? ](https://medcitynews.com/2024/04/walgreens-specialty-pharmacy-drugs/)
Walgreens announced that it is expanding its specialty pharmacy offerings. Experts think that this move could yield several strategic benefits, given the higher profit margins associated with specialty medications compared to traditional drugs. They also think Walgreens’ move could lead to greater competition, consolidation, and innovation within the broader pharmacy industry.
By KATIE ADAMS - MEDCITY NEWS

# Honoring Advocates For Women's Equality In The Legal Profession
## Do you know who Inez Milholland was? If you don't, you should get to know her -- and these other leading figures in the fight for gender equity.
By [David Lat](https://abovethelaw.com/author/david-lat/)  
onJuly 30, 2019 at 2:48 PMAugust 20, 2019 at 7:29 PM
53
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/07/honoring-advocates-for-womens-equality-in-the-legal-profession/&text=Honoring%20Advocates%20For%20Women’s%20Equality%20In%20The%20Legal%20Profession)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/07/honoring-advocates-for-womens-equality-in-the-legal-profession/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/07/honoring-advocates-for-womens-equality-in-the-legal-profession/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inez_Milholland)
Inez Milholland, on horseback, leading the March 3, 1913 Woman Suffrage Procession in Washington, D.C. (Public domain photo via Wikimedia.)

Next year marks the centennial of women’s suffrage in the United States. In 1920, the Nineteenth Amendment to the Constitution was ratified, providing that “[t]he right of citizens of the United States to vote shall not be denied or abridged by the United States or by any State on account of sex.”

Perhaps surprisingly to some, women were able to practice law in the United States before they were able to vote. Indeed, at the time of the passage of the Nineteenth Amendment, the [National Association of Women Lawyers](https://www.nawl.org/) (NAWL) had some 170 members in 25 states — and many of NAWL’s members played leading roles in the movement for women’s suffrage.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
I learned this and many other interesting historical facts about women lawyers in the United States when I had the pleasure of attending NAWL’s [2019 Annual Meeting and Awards Luncheon](https://www.nawl.org/2019annualmeeting), which took place here in New York earlier this month. ([Cadence Counsel](https://www.mainspringlegal.com/cadencecounsel/) — the in-house division of [Lateral Link](https://www.mainspringlegal.com/laterallink/), where I [now work](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/05/a-departure-memo-from-david-lat-leaving-abovethelaw-joining-lateral-link/) — was a proud sponsor of the event, so we had a table.)

In her opening remarks, [Kristin Sostowski](https://www.gibbonslaw.com/professionals/kristin-d-sostowski), a partner at Gibbons and the 2019-2020 president of NAWL, discussed the role of the organization and its members in promoting women’s suffrage. In particular, she highlighted the work of [Inez Milholland](https://time.com/4391874/the-society-girl-who-became-a-martyr-for-womens-suffrage/), a lawyer and activist who became famous for her advocacy of women’s rights.

After graduating from [Vassar College](http://vcencyclopedia.vassar.edu/alumni/inez-milholland.html) in 1909, Milholland applied to the law schools of Harvard, Yale, and Columbia, but was rejected on the basis of her sex. After graduating from NYU Law in 1912, she devoted her legal career to advancing equality for women, workers, and people of color (she was a member of the NAACP as well as NAWL). She was especially known for her work on women’s suffrage, leading the giant 1913 suffrage parade in Washington — on horseback, no less — and going on a national speaking tour for the cause.

Sadly, Inez Milholland did not live to see women’s suffrage become a nationwide reality. She died in 1916, three years before ratification of the Nineteenth Amendment, collapsing onstage at a suffrage event in Los Angeles. She was hospitalized for what turned out to be an untreated infection of her tonsils, passing away 10 weeks later. She was just 30 years old at the time of her death — and her martyrdom helped [advance the cause of women’s suffrage](https://time.com/4391874/the-society-girl-who-became-a-martyr-for-womens-suffrage/), which became the law in her home state of New York the following year.

Milholland continues to inspire advocates for women’s equality, in both society at large and in the legal profession specifically. NAWL president Kristin Sostowski said that she often asks herself, “What would Inez do?” But as Sostowski reminded the NAWL luncheon attendees, even though Milholland accomplished so much in her all-too-short life, so much work remains to be done.

[](https://abovethelaw.com/uploads/2019/07/NAWL-board-2019-2020.jpg)
The board of the National Association of Women Lawyers (NAWL), 2019-2020. (Courtesy of NAWL – photo by Pablo Corradi.)

And NAWL and its members are doing that work. At the lunch, the organization presented the Virginia S. Mueller Award to four of the group’s most outstanding members: [Susan Alker](https://www.linkedin.com/in/susanalker/), COO and general counsel of Crescent Cove Advisors LLC; [Elizabeth Banzhoff](https://www.perkinscoie.com/en/professionals/elizabeth-m-banzhoff.html), counsel at Perkins Coie; [Tamela Merriweather](https://www.linkedin.com/in/tamela-woods-merriweather-72755033/), senior vice president and assistant general counsel at Northern Trust Corporation; and [Heather Stenmark](https://www.linkedin.com/in/heather-stenmark-a061624/), counsel at Allstate Insurance Company.

Of course, the fight for women’s equality in the legal profession is not just a fight waged by women. NAWL bestowed the Lead By Example Award to [James Chosy](https://www.law.com/corpcounsel/2018/12/10/us-banks-james-chosy-where-tech-leads-so-do-in-house-lawyers/), executive vice president and general counsel at U.S. Bancorp, for being a leading male attorney who supports the advancement of women within his organization. At U.S. Bancorp, the [fifth-largest](https://www.usbank.com/about-us-bank.html) bank in the country, Chosy has achieved the impressive feat of building a legal department that is more than two-thirds women — and where women make up a whopping 78 percent of lawyers in senior leadership.

Inequality comes in many forms, and some have to overcome multiple forms of disadvantage in order to advance in the legal profession. Consider the story of [Grace Speights](https://www.morganlewis.com/bios/gspeights), recipient of NAWL’s M. Ashley Dickerson Award, which recognizes lawyers who promote diversity.

From Pilot and Above The Law  
Speights, an African-American woman, grew up in Philadelphia below the poverty line, raised by a single mother who worked in a drapery factory. Despite these challenging circumstances, Speights graduated from the University of Pennsylvania and the George Washington University Law School (Order of the Coif), clerked for a federal judge, and went on to become one of the nation’s leading employment lawyers. Today she leads the labor and employment practice of Morgan Lewis & Bockius — and does all she can, both as a lawyer with her clients and in her work outside the firm, to ensure inclusive and respectful workplaces and to advance diversity in the law.

The last two awards both went to organizations — fittingly enough, because combating inequality requires coordinated and collective action. The NAWL President’s Award, given for championing policies and programs to retain and promote women attorneys, went to USAA, the Fortune 500 company that offers diversified financial services to people and families who serve or served in the U.S. military. The Arabella Babb Mansfield Award, given for professional achievement, positive influence, and valuable contribution to women in the law and in society, went to the ACLU Women’s Rights Project, for its many decades of dedication to advancing the equality of women under the law.

All in all, NAWL’s 2019 Annual Meeting and Awards Luncheon was both educational and inspiring, a wonderful opportunity to honor leading advocates for women’s equality in the legal profession. I look forward to attending this event in the future — and to celebrating future leaders in the movement for gender equity in the law.

[David Lat](https://davidlat.com/), the founding editor of Above the Law, is a [writer](https://davidlat.com/writing/), [speaker](https://davidlat.com/speaking/), and [legal recruiter at Lateral Link](https://www.mainspringlegal.com/team/david-lat/), where he is a managing director in the New York office. David’s book, [Supreme Ambitions: A Novel](http://bit.ly/SupremeAmbitions) (2014), was described by the New York Times as “the most buzzed-about novel of the year” among legal elites. David previously worked as a federal prosecutor, a litigation associate at Wachtell Lipton, and a law clerk to Judge Diarmuid F. O’Scannlain of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. You can connect with David on [Twitter (@DavidLat)](http://bit.ly/2BMTF1R), [LinkedIn](http://bit.ly/2E9v0tq), and [Facebook](http://bit.ly/2nxIENN), and you can reach him by email at [dlat@laterallink.com](mailto:dlat@laterallink.com).

# Partner Describes Biglaw's Economics Perfectly: 'Unrealistic, Unhealthy, Inhumane'
## It's so true.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJuly 11, 2023 at 4:12 PMJuly 11, 2023 at 1:16 PM
5
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/07/partner-describes-biglaws-economics-perfectly-unrealistic-unhealthy-inhumane/&text=Partner%20Describes%20Biglaw’s%20Economics%20Perfectly:%20‘Unrealistic,%20Unhealthy,%20Inhumane’)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/07/partner-describes-biglaws-economics-perfectly-unrealistic-unhealthy-inhumane/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/07/partner-describes-biglaws-economics-perfectly-unrealistic-unhealthy-inhumane/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Ed. note: Welcome to our daily feature, [Quote of the Day](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/quote-of-the-day/).

It turns out that [Biglaw] has a problem with economics. The nature of that problem is that all economies are cyclical. Over time, in any economy, in any market place, output will grow, then decline, then recover, then decline. This doesn’t suit [Biglaw], which only wants to see steady gains. …

The problem isn’t that economies are cyclical, that’s a fact of life. The problem here is that [Biglaw] can sometimes have unrealistic reactions to both upturns and downturns. If this happens, it’s not in the interests of their own attorneys or their clients. It’s inhumane and unhealthy.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
— [Alex Geisler](https://www.duanemorris.com/attorneys/alexandermgeisler.html), a London-based litigation partner with Duane Morris, in an article originally published in [ALM’s Accounting and Financial Planning for Law Firms](https://www.law.com/2023/07/07/the-way-big-law-reacts-to-economic-cycles-is-unrealistic-unhealthy-and-inhumane/), on the “unrealistic reactions” Biglaw has to economic upturns (i.e., big raises, big bonuses, and big hiring booms) and downturns (i.e., layoffs and deferrals).

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky).

# Oh My, O'Melveny
## Just write a memo, people.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onApril 1, 2021 at 11:45 AMApril 1, 2021 at 11:10 AM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/04/omelveny-special-bonuses/&text=Oh%20My,%20O’Melveny)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/04/omelveny-special-bonuses/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/04/omelveny-special-bonuses/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Why do firms announce compensation news over voicemail? It’s not like these bonuses will never leak out if only they avoid leaving a paper trail. No one actually likes listening to long voicemails. The best feature of modern smartphones is that they transcribe the voicemails for you so you don’t have to listen to figure out what’s going on.

And yet some firms stand by the self-indulgent voicemail speech, failing to appreciate that every associate is rolling their eyes with the message on speaker just waiting for the good part.

O’Melveny apparently opted for the voicemail.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
Since the firm technically has “Myers” in the name, we’ll give the bonus its proper Myers-Briggs name of[ a MSBLDPWM](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/03/pillsbury-special-bonus/).

May 31	Sept 30	Total
Class of 2020	$4,500	$7,500	$12,000
Class of 2019	$6,000	$10,000	$16,000
Class of 2018	$12,000	$20,000	$32,000
Class of 2017	$16,500	$27,500	$44,000
Class of 2016	$19,500	$32,500	$52,000
Class of 2015	$22,200	$37,000	$59,200
Class of 2014 & up	$24,000	$40,000	$64,000
Though maybe it’s more fair to say it’s “JO” since that’s functionally a June/October breakdown. In any event, back-loaded DPW matches for all U.S. and Asia associates and counsel hitting an annualized 1900 hours based on detection points of April 30 and August 31.

This is where I’d usually say that the memo is attached on the next page, but there is no memo. Maybe I’ll just record myself doing a dramatic reading of this article and post that later.

[Morning Docket](https://abovethelaw.com/morning-docket/)
# Morning Docket: 11.01.16
## * Is there a constitutional right to smoke weed? This defendant says he was prescribed medical marijuana to help him kick an opioid addiction, and his bail conditions must be revised to allow him to keep smoking it, lest his Sixth Amendment right to participate fully in his own defense be impaired. How high were the Katten Muchin lawyers who thought up this creative defense? [[Reuters](http://reuters.com/article/USLegal/idUSL1N1D11GJ?il=0)] * Baker Donelson plans to merge with Ober Kaler to create one of the largest Biglaw firms in the country. Effective January 1, the firm will have more than 800 attorneys, and one of the largest health law practices in America. The $400+ million in revenue expected to be brought in by the merger isn't too shabby, either. [[Big Law Business](https://bol.bna.com/merger-plans-to-create-law-firm-among-50-largest-in-u-s/)] * "[N]o one is dragging their feet here. The Justice Department is committed to working with the FBI to move the case forward." AG Loretta Lynch and Deputy AG Sally Yates are trying to get FBI Director James Comey to wrap up his renewed interest in the Hillary Clinton email probe as quickly as possible before the election next week. [[Politico](http://www.politico.com/story/2016/10/justice-fbi-clinton-emails-230549)] * "You haven’t been able to do it with trademark law. You haven’t been able to do it with patent designs. We are now going to use copyright law to kill the knockoff industry. I don't know that that's bad. I'm just saying." Differing opinions about the fashion industry emerged during oral arguments in the Star Athletica case. [[New York Times](http://nytimes.com/2016/11/01/us/politics/in-a-copyright-case-justices-ponder-the-fashion-industry.html)] * "We are all feeling a little less confident. ... [T]here is an incredible amount of uncertainty that comes with this." Some U.S. firms with offices in London and Europe are contemplating what Brexit's effects will be on their business -- or if Brexit will have any effect on their business at all. At this point, no one knows. [[Philadelphia Inquirer](http://www.philly.com/philly/business/Law-firms-face-Brexit-uncertainty.html)]
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onNovember 1, 2016 at 8:58 AMOctober 31, 2016 at 10:50 PM
1

###Above The Law In your inbox

We will never sell or share your information without your consent. See our [privacy policy](/privacy-policy/).
[Morning Docket](https://abovethelaw.com/morning-docket/)
# Morning Docket: 09.22.17
## * According to a lawsuit filed against the NFL and the New England Patriots by Aaron Hernandez's family, the former football player who was serving a life sentence for murder at the time of his death had a "severe case" of CTE. Jose Baez, the family's attorney, said Hernandez had "the most severe case [researchers] had ever seen for someone of Aaron’s age." [[CBS Boston](http://boston.cbslocal.com/2017/09/21/aaron-hernandez-cte-results-jose-baez/)] * A man after Trump's own heart: During a recent speaking engagement, Justice Neil Gorsuch explained why he believes judges ought to be conservative on the bench, saying that "the job of the judge to apply it, not amend the law ... even when he might well prefer a very different outcome." Later, he said judges must stick to interpreting laws instead of rewriting them. [[Associated Press](https://apnews.com/f4db85d505434a3bb66265da4475b710/Supreme-Court's-Gorsuch-touts-conservative-role-for-judges)] * Uh-oh. Skadden is under fire for work the firm did for Paul Manafort five years ago. Apparently Manafort asked the firm to write a report justifying the jailing of a client's political rival, and it's coming back to haunt them. The DOJ wants the firm to hand over all documents having to do with the matter. [[New York Times](https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/21/us/politics/law-firm-faces-questions-for-ukraine-work-with-manafort.html)] * After being fired by President Donald Trump for her refusal to defend the travel ban, former Acting U.S. Attorney General Sally Yates has found a new home, at least for this semester. Yates will serve as a Distinguished Lecturer from Government at Georgetown Law. Congratulations! [[Law.com](http://www.law.com/sites/almstaff/2017/09/21/sally-yates-finds-perch-at-georgetown-law/)] * In an effort to bring on-campus residential life back for law students -- and thanks to alumni donations totaling $60 million -- Yale Law is expanding its campus for the first time in almost 100 years. Construction on the new dorm is expected to be completed by the end of next summer. [[Yale Daily News](http://yaledailynews.com/blog/2017/09/21/law-school-begins-historic-expansion/)]
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onSeptember 22, 2017 at 8:49 AMSeptember 21, 2017 at 11:07 PM
1

# Top 25 Biglaw Firm Hands Out Even More Money (On Top Of Bonuses)
## This firm cares about its everyone's mental health, and they're paying for it.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onMay 5, 2021 at 12:12 PMMay 5, 2021 at 12:08 PM
11
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/05/goodwin-mental-health-money/&text=Top%2025%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Hands%20Out%20Even%20More%20Money%20(On%20Top%20Of%20Bonuses))[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/05/goodwin-mental-health-money/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/05/goodwin-mental-health-money/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Members of the legal profession are keenly aware that the pandemic has brought about even more stress and anxiety than usual. Working from home thanks to the coronavirus crisis completely stripped down the illusion of work-life balance, and many associates have found themselves forced into a situation where they’re constantly “on duty,” even more so than before the COVID-19 crush began.

But with a renewed focus on mental health, some Biglaw firms are trying to invest more heavily into their attorneys’ well-being. As luck would have it, May is Mental Health Awareness Month, and this week is Well-Being Week in Law. One top law firm, Goodwin Procter, is showing its lawyers the love this week, in the form of a $1,000 well-being payment for all eligible non-partner lawyers, science advisors, and science law clerks in good standing in the U.S., U.K., Hong Kong, and Luxembourg. Here’s an excerpt from a memo the firm sent out yesterday afternoon (full memo available on the next page):

As you continue to work extremely hard on behalf of our clients, we want to ensure that you are also taking care of yourself. To this end, we are awarding a one-time $1,000 wellbeing payment to all eligible non-partner lawyers, science advisors and science law clerks in good standing. The gross payment of $1,000 (minus applicable taxes) will be paid in the May payroll to those employed on this month’s payroll date who have not given notice.

You may use this $1,000 payment however you would like to engage in self-care and to defray costs you have incurred during this extended period of remote work – like takeout meals while working long hours or new exercise equipment. You will not need to submit receipts.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Goodwin is continuing to make an effort to support its employees during these trying times. If you recall, the firm previously [handed out $1,500 in two separate payments](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/12/goodwin-tech-money/) to defray the costs of working from home (e.g., well-being, meals, technology, supplies, and other expenses incurred due to remote work). At the same time, the firm announced special bonuses for paralegals, ranging from $8,000 to $20,000, depending on seniority and hours billed (memo available on the next page). The firm is really doing its part to make up for the fact that it earlier conducted a series of [staff](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/even-a-billion-dollars-in-revenue-cant-stop-covid-19-layoffs/) and [attorney layoffs](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/05/goodwin-stealth-layoffs/) during the height of the pandemic.

As always, we depend on you when it comes to bonus news at other firms. As soon as your firm’s bonus memo comes out, please [email it to us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Bonus) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Bonus”) or text us (646-820-8477). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts, please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish.

# The Evolution Of Legal Teams: Looking To The Future
## How the decisions your team makes today are shaping its tomorrow.
By Above The Law and Filevine  
onJanuary 6, 2023 at 12:15 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/01/the-evolution-of-legal-teams-looking-to-the-future/&text=The%20Evolution%20Of%20Legal%20Teams:%20Looking%20To%20The%20Future)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/01/the-evolution-of-legal-teams-looking-to-the-future/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/01/the-evolution-of-legal-teams-looking-to-the-future/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Over the years, legal work has changed. But those changes are accelerating in today’s environment.

The challenges and responsibilities legal teams face are growing, too. And they’re becoming critical to solve.

In this eBook, our friends at Filevine uncover the nuances of what a legal team looks like today, demonstrate how the tools for legal work have evolved, and explore how the decisions legal teams make today are shaping their tomorrow.

Download it to ensure your team can hit the ground running in the new year.

####Topics
[2023](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/2023/), [Biglaw](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/biglaw/), [Filevine](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/filevine/), [Small Law Firms](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/small-law-firms-topic/), [Sponsored Content](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/sponsored-content/)

# 3 Ways To Strengthen Your Bond With In-House Counsel Through Secondment
## Secondment can provide a greater understanding for how to better serve clients in private practice.
By Lisa Lang and Florence Z. Mao  
onJanuary 13, 2023 at 11:17 AMJanuary 20, 2023 at 10:44 AM
2
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/01/3-ways-to-strengthen-your-bond-with-in-house-counsel-through-secondment/&text=3%20Ways%20To%20Strengthen%20Your%20Bond%20With%20In-House%20Counsel%20Through%20Secondment)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/01/3-ways-to-strengthen-your-bond-with-in-house-counsel-through-secondment/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/01/3-ways-to-strengthen-your-bond-with-in-house-counsel-through-secondment/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Before landing my first in-house role, I read everything I could get my hands on about making the transition from private practice to in-house. Not only was I interested in how lawyers made the move, I was also interested in reading what I could about whether it was a move I wanted to make. From what I was reading, making the move was not easy and not always what it was cracked up to be.

Recently, I chatted with my good friend Florence Z. Mao, a senior associate at Ogletree Deakins, who shared with me that she was where I was those many years ago. She was in private practice, but she was interested in seeing what it would be like to move in-house. Flo did more than read about what it was like to work in-house. Flo temporarily made the move in-house through a secondment. Whether she decides to move in-house or not, Flo shared with me that her secondment allowed her to do something even more important. It provided her with an opportunity to gain a perspective that did not have before. With this perspective, she would be able to serve her clients better and bond with her client’s in-house lawyers in a way she had not done before.

What is a secondment?

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)

The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
It is when a lawyer is assigned by the lawyer’s firm to work temporarily for a client company for the purpose of meeting the workforce needs of that understaffed company due to a company employee’s absence.

What did Flo learn?

I will let Flo tell you in her own words. As an in-house lawyer, I would have to say that she hits the mark with her assessment. I am now an absolute fan of secondments. What a great way to strengthen the partnership between outside counsel and in-house counsel.

3 Ways To Strengthen Your Bond With In-House Counsel

From Pilot and Above The Law  
In the last five months, I’ve had the privilege of seconding at a large technology company as their in-house employment counsel. Before this experience, I’d spent my entire career at law firms. It was eye-opening to finally see things from a client’s perspective. Now that I’m returning to private practice, I’d like to share three lessons I’ve learned during my secondment to help outside counsel build stronger relationships with in-house attorneys.

1. Respond, Respond, Respond.

In-house attorneys juggle multiple balls at any given time. Sometimes a question to outside counsel is for general enrichment (i.e., “What is XYZ new law in New York?”) or to prepare for an upcoming internal initiative. Other times, the question is more urgent. Maybe a C-level executive is asking for information to make critical decisions. Maybe it’s a tricky personnel issue and HR is waiting for an answer to take next steps right away.

Even if you don’t know the answer and need time to research, responding to acknowledge the request can assure in-house attorneys that you’re on it. By letting them know that you’re “on it,” they can move to the next fire they need to put out. Just as an associate might check with their partner on when an assignment is due, ask when your client might need an answer. The response may surprise you — they often need it ASAP.

2. Bedside Manner Matters.

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
If in-house attorneys are contacting you, they know that you’re the subject matter expert. You’ve spent hours becoming an expert. They’re contacting you because they’re unfamiliar with the area of law. Talking in an intelligent, but approachable, way can make a difference here

For example, I was on a call with outside counsel to discuss an international legal issue. Our paralegal wasn’t available for the call, but I told counsel I would fill them in afterward. Outside counsel then asked me a question about the underlying issue, and followed up with, “Or is that a paralegal question?” Even if counsel didn’t mean it this way, it sounded dismissive and left a bad taste in my mouth. In-house attorneys and paralegals work as a team — they’re often on the same page about major issues, so not everyone needs to attend a meeting.

As another example, a director-level employee and I had a call with outside counsel on a complex area of law. When outside counsel asked a question and the director began to answer, counsel would cut the director off and not let them finish. This occurred many times during a 20-minute call. After the call, the director called me to complain about outside counsel. While virtual calls are not easy, be intentional about how you interact with in-house attorneys and their only client – company employees.

3. Put Your Recommendation At The Top Of The Email.

In-house attorneys get many emails and phone calls from different departments throughout the day. They are often pulled in multiple directions. Some issues they deal with are easily disposed of, but others require intense negotiation with internal stakeholders and contain time-consuming problems to solve. As a result, emails that are long, winding, and don’t provide clear recommendations are exhausting and frustrating to read.

While it’s important as outside counsel to “cover your bases” and make sure clients have all the information they need to make a decision, you’ll be recognized as a true business partner if you can succinctly recommend a course of action at the get-go. Put your recommendation at the top of the email in one or two sentences. Then explain your reasoning in more detail. In-house attorneys will appreciate your clean and crisp communication and return with more business.

My secondment has provided a greater understanding for how I can better serve my clients in private practice. Bottom line is that in-house attorneys are almost always dealing with multiple fires on any given day. The best way we, as outside counsel, can support them is to partner with them to achieve the best outcome. The three strategies above will take you there.

Florence Z. Mao is a senior associate at Ogletree Deakins, one of the largest labor and employment law firms in the United States. She helps businesses of all sizes comply with ever-changing employment laws and mitigate risk against potential legal claims.

Lisa Lang is an in-house lawyer and thought leader who is passionate about all things in-house.  She has recently launched a website and blog Why This, Not That™ (www.lawyerlisalang.com ) to serve as a resource for in-house lawyers.  You can e-mail her at [lisa@lawyerlisalang.com](mailto:lisa@lawyerlisalang.com) , connect with her on LinkedIn  ([https://www.linkedin.com/in/lawyerlisalang/](https://www.linkedin.com/in/lawyerlisalang/)) or follow her on Twitter (@lang_lawyer).

# Greenberg Traurig Offers Voluntary Buyouts With 'Enhanced' Severance
## This is much better than layoffs.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onOctober 16, 2020 at 12:12 PMOctober 16, 2020 at 11:50 AM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/10/greenberg-traurig-offers-voluntary-buyouts-with-enhanced-severance/&text=Greenberg%20Traurig%20Offers%20Voluntary%20Buyouts%20With%20‘Enhanced’%20Severance)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/10/greenberg-traurig-offers-voluntary-buyouts-with-enhanced-severance/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/10/greenberg-traurig-offers-voluntary-buyouts-with-enhanced-severance/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
For the past seven months, the coronavirus crisis has ravaged the legal profession, leading to salary cuts, furloughs, and in some cases, layoffs. But some firms seem to have remained completely unscathed by the global economic turmoil that’s been caused by COVID-19.
Take Greenberg Traurig, a firm that brought in $1,641,790,000 in gross revenue last year, earning it 14th place in the latest Am Law 100 ranking, for example. Back in April, we [reported](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/more-good-news-from-biglaw-firms-not-cutting-back/) that the firm had offered “a good deal of transparency about [its] financial position” and assured attorneys that there would be no layoffs. At that time, there had been no word of salary cuts at the firm, and to our knowledge, throughout the pandemic, no such cuts were made. The firm made it quite far without having to take any major cost-cutting measures, but sources have told us that GT has now decided to roll out a voluntary separation program for full-time staff.

An internal memo states that while the firm remains in a “strong financial position,” many “roles and responsibilities have inevitably shifted” due to the firm’s remote working environment, and that some employees had allegedly asked if Greenberg Traurig would offer a voluntary separation program so they could pursue “other professional, personal, or academic opportunities” outside of the firm. Ask and you shall apparently receive, GT employees. Eligible staff members for the separation program include legal assistants, administrative assistants, administrative clerks, file clerks, records clerks, and hospitality assistants. Here are the details of the plan’s “enhanced incentive offers” for employees to voluntarily leave the firm:

### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
As noted above, eligible staff members will have until November 15 to decide if they want to take advantage of this program.

(Flip to the next page to see the full buyout memo from Greenberg Traurig.)

We reached out to Greenberg Traurig for comment on the firm’s buyout plan. Here is a statement we received from a firm spokesperson:

We are proud of the fact that our disciplined management, our balanced platform, our committed shareholders, putting our people first, and allowing us to solidly perform thus far in 2020, have allowed us to avoid any across-the-board layoffs or compensation reductions for our lawyers or staff at any levels this year, notwithstanding the pandemic. However, as we now look forward and plan for our future, and what our clients’ and lawyers’ needs are likely to be, we felt remote working has made this program sensible at this time. It is being offered to a majority of our US offices.

We wish all of the legal professionals at Greenberg Traurig who accept the buyout offer the best of luck should they seek new jobs in the legal industry.

If your firm or organization is slashing salaries, closing its doors, or reducing the ranks of its lawyers or staff, whether through open layoffs, stealth layoffs, or voluntary buyouts, please don’t hesitate to let us know. Our vast network of tipsters is part of what makes Above the Law thrive. You can [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Layoffs/Salary%20Cuts) or text us (646-820-8477).

# 'The Longest-Lived Dead Law Firm In The Western World'
## Years after its dissolution, this law firm is making news headlines today for its latest -- possibly final -- legal victory.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onFebruary 18, 2016 at 4:18 PMFebruary 18, 2016 at 4:22 PM
21
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/02/the-longest-lived-dead-law-firm-in-the-western-world/&text=‘The%20Longest-Lived%20Dead%20Law%20Firm%20In%20The%20Western%20World’)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/02/the-longest-lived-dead-law-firm-in-the-western-world/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/02/the-longest-lived-dead-law-firm-in-the-western-world/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))


A federal judge just approved a deal between a Biglaw firm and “the longest-lived dead law firm in the Western World.” To what defunct Biglaw firm, founded in the 1853 and dissolved in 2006, was she referring?

Hint: Lawyers in the case were quick to point out that, in fact, Brobeck is the longest living dead law firm, still kicking around in the California bankruptcy system 13 years after its death.

Highlight the below text with your mouse for the answer.

Answer: Coudert Brothers, founded by brothers Frederic René Coudert, Sr., Charles Coudert, Jr., and Louis Leonce Coudert. The international law-focused firm had an impressive history. Frederic himself was [tapped for the U.S. Supreme Court by Grover Cleveland](http://query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9902E3DF1139E333A25752C2A9649D946297D6CF) and declined the offer — the slot eventually went to Justice Edward White who would later go on to serve as Chief Justice.

# In-Person Meetings With Adversaries Can Be Valuable
## The best way to build rapport with a counterpart can be to meet in person.
By [Jordan Rothman](https://abovethelaw.com/author/jordanrothman/)  
onApril 27, 2022 at 5:47 PMApril 27, 2022 at 3:42 PM
2
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/04/in-person-meetings-with-adversaries-can-be-valuable/&text=In-Person%20Meetings%20With%20Adversaries%20Can%20Be%20Valuable)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/04/in-person-meetings-with-adversaries-can-be-valuable/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/04/in-person-meetings-with-adversaries-can-be-valuable/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Over the past two years, lawyers have been conducting meetings remotely that often used to take place in person before the COVID-19 pandemic. Of course, it makes sense that people would favor virtual meetings during the pandemic rather than in-person ones in order to promote social distancing and keep people safe. However, as people ease back into the new normal now that COVID-19 has subsided to some degree, lawyers and courts are operating in person in many contexts just like before the pandemic. Lawyers should also try to meet adversaries in person more often whenever they can now that operations are somewhat returning to normal so that attorneys can realize the benefits of in-person meetups.

When I was an associate in Biglaw, I rarely, if ever, met any of my adversaries in person. I rarely went to court to argue motions or for other appearances since only the senior lawyers on my team were trusted to argue matters in court. In addition, since the matters were so big, clients rarely wanted me and other junior attorneys to be involved in meetings. Of course, sometimes I would tag along with senior lawyers, but this was a rare event, and I was scarcely an active participant in such meetings.

When I left Biglaw for a smaller firm, I had a much more active role in managing my files. This required me to deal with clients, adversaries, witnesses, and other stakeholders to the legal profession. In order to ensure that things went smoothly, it was often necessary to have a good rapport with adversaries. Sometimes, it was easy enough to build rapport over the phone, but I quickly found out that the best way to build rapport with a counterpart was to meet an adversary in person.

One time, I was involved in a massive document production with an adversary. The document production was intense since we were claiming privilege and other protections, and I had to compile a massive privilege log detailing the documents we withheld from the production on the basis of some kind of protection. A handful of the documents were being reviewed in camera by the court, but my adversary and I were coming to arrangements about some of the documents, which lessened the burden of the court in reviewing the materials.

At one part of the project, I had to produce documents to the adversary. I noticed that the adversary had his office across the street from me. I suggested to my adversary that rather than mail the documents to my counterpart, I could just hand-deliver the documents to him at his office. The weather was pretty nice, and it was no problem taking a short walk to hand deliver the documents.

When I got to my adversary’s office, he seemed happy that I took the time to hand deliver the documents rather than impersonally dropping the documents in the mail. We had a nice conversation, and then we parted ways. After meeting my adversary for the first time in person, it was much easier to work through the document production together. This was likely due to the fact that my adversary and I could now put a face to a name and felt like we had more of a connection than we did just talking on the phone and exchanging emails.

More recently, I was working on a landlord-tenant matter with an adversary, and the negotiation became heated at times. My adversary kept gaslighting me by relating that I was requesting language that was not common and that was not needed due to the mechanics of the agreement we were negotiating. At one point my adversary said that working with me was like getting an IV in the wrong direction. If someone can explain this metaphor to me, I’d appreciate it; I still have a hard time wrapping my head around what my adversary meant!

In any event, when it came time to exchange the executed documents and the payment, it would have been simple enough to drop the materials in the mail. Nevertheless, I thought it would be easier and more personal if I hand-delivered all of the materials to my adversary’s office. The walk was not that bad, and when I met my adversary face to face, all of the tension in the negotiation was gone. We had a nice conversation about our careers, and then we exchanged our documents and ensured that everyone had a copy of all of the relevant materials. The rest of the deal went by without a hitch, likely owing to the fact that my adversary and I built rapport with our in-person meeting.

All told, as we all emerge from our COVID-19 cocoons, lawyers should consider meeting their adversaries in person more often. This can help build rapport that can be critical to ensuring that lawyers have an easier time working with each other.

Jordan Rothman is a partner of [The Rothman Law Firm](http://www.rothmanlawyer.com/), a full-service New York and New Jersey law firm. He is also the founder of [Student Debt Diaries](https://studentdebtdiaries.com/), a website discussing how he paid off his student loans. You can reach Jordan through email at [jordan@rothman.law](mailto:jordan@rothman.law?subject=Your%20ATL%20column).

# Top 20 Biglaw Firm Reportedly Raises Salaries -- But Not For All Class Years, And Not For All Offices
## Salaries are being handled quite secretly at the firm.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJuly 12, 2021 at 11:50 AMJuly 12, 2021 at 12:03 PM
10
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/07/greenberg-traurig-raise-2021/&text=Top%2020%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Reportedly%20Raises%20Salaries%20—%20But%20Not%20For%20All%20Class%20Years,%20And%20Not%20For%20All%20Offices)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/07/greenberg-traurig-raise-2021/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/07/greenberg-traurig-raise-2021/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Image via Getty)

It’s been a little more than a month since Davis Polk raised the bar on associate salaries, and while the vast majority of top Biglaw firms have already raised salaries in some form or fashion, we’re still waiting for confirmation from several elite firms on what, exactly, they’re planning to do when it comes to associate compensation.

On that note, we’d love to find out what is going on at Greenberg Traurig. With $1,730,230,000 gross revenue in 2020, the firm placed 16th in the most recent Am Law 100 rankings, but from what we’ve heard, the firm has reportedly only raised salaries for associates in New York — but not all associates, mind you.

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
Sources tell us that sometime between June 21 and June 24, the firm increased salaries for first-year associates to $205K. As far as other class years are concerned, we’ve heard that salaries may be individualized beyond the class of 2020, but with raises comparable to the new Davis Polk scale.

Now, what of associates outside of New York? That’s another story entirely. Insiders at the firm tells us the tale:

“[N]o raises have occurred in a major, non-New York market. The issue hasn’t been discussed, and the firm tends to handle these matters secretively and by office. Same happened with special bonuses: associates were informed on an office-by-office basis with a phone call and nothing in writing, so we don’t know what happens across offices.”

“GT is individually assessing each associate in select offices but it seems like unless there is extreme performance, the vast majority of associates won’t be getting raises. Per usual, GT is trying to keep everything a secret and telling associates not to tell each other anything.

The black box system is worse than Jones Day. At least people know about Jones Day, but GT gets away with murder. GT never puts anything in writing for fear of info being discussed among employees or ending up on Above the Law, so people would only hear about their raises and salaries verbally.”

So, GT associates: what do you think about your raises (or curious lack thereof)? Feel free to sound off [by email](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=GT%202021%20Raises), by text message (646-820-8477), or by tweet ([@ATLblog](https://twitter.com/atlblog)). A fun or insightful response — we’ll keep you anonymous — could find its way into an update to this story.

We depend on your tips to stay on top of this stuff. So when your firm matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts (which is the alert list we’ll also use for salary announcements), please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish.

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky-6344b322).

# The White Sandal Elite: The Go-To Law Firms of Silicon Valley
## Which firms are the best in Silicon Valley?
By [Brian Dalton](https://abovethelaw.com/author/brian-dalton/)  
onMay 4, 2016 at 4:33 PMMay 5, 2016 at 3:15 PM
129
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/05/the-white-sandal-elite-the-go-to-law-firms-of-silicon-valley/&text=The%20White%20Sandal%20Elite:%20The%20Go-To%20Law%20Firms%20of%20Silicon%20Valley)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/05/the-white-sandal-elite-the-go-to-law-firms-of-silicon-valley/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/05/the-white-sandal-elite-the-go-to-law-firms-of-silicon-valley/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

One of the big takeaways from the just released [2016 Amlaw 100](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/04/the-2016-am-law-100-trouble-ahead/?utm_source=ATL&utm_medium=Native%20Content&utm_campaign=2016%20AMLAW%20POST) numbers is that, although white-shoe New York firms have recently struggled for growth, their Silicon Valley peers are ascendant, thanks to a “frothy” tech market and the resultant IPO and M&A work. Of course, the Silicon Valley legal market extends well beyond the cadre of elite Biglaw players such as Wilson Sonsini, Cooley, and Fenwick to include a complex ecosystem of specialist boutiques and smaller firms with deep local roots and thriving practices in areas ranging from estate planning to restructuring to white collar defense.

Our friends at [Lake Whillans Litigation Finance](http://lakewhillans.com/?utm_source=ATL&utm_medium=Native%20Content&utm_campaign=LW%20HOMEPAGE) recently [opened](http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/litigation-finance-leader-lake-whillans-expands-opening-palo-alto-office-300230623.html?utm_source=ATL&utm_medium=Native%20Content&utm_campaign=LW%20EXPANDS%20POST) a new Palo Alto office to better serve its Silicon Valley-based clients, including entrepreneurs and venture capital firms. To celebrate this new outpost, Lake Whillans is sponsoring this handy primer to the “white sandal” firms of Silicon Valley. Among them, these firms not only can handle every transactional need, but also do anything from taxes to setting up HR review processes.

Engaging these firms can help the tech startups, unicorns, and venture capitalists of the new economy avoid or contain problems down the road. Should legal issues arise, Lake Whillans can step in and help resolve them.

If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…

##1. Best Firm for Incorporating Your Two-Person Company Because Somebody Told You There Were Tax Benefits: [Fortis General Counsel, LLP](http://www.fortisgc.com/?utm_source=ATL&utm_medium=Native%20Content&utm_campaign=FORTIS)


This tiny boutique firm boasts a flexible business model and has found success in providing the legal services that are typically performed in-house, making them the ideal firm for a new company that lacks its own general counsel. The firm’s three lawyers are emerging company specialists who specialize in advising early-stage startups, particularly in the technology sector. Known throughout Silicon Valley for their cost-effective representation of tech companies in all aspects of business law, they are your go-to resource when your company is just getting off the ground.

##2. Best Firm For Patenting Your Algorithm or Application: [Wilson Sonsini Goodrich & Rosati PC](https://www.wsgr.com/?utm_source=ATL&utm_medium=Native%20Content&utm_campaign=WSGR)

Founded in Silicon Valley, this global firm now boasts 15 offices worldwide and has become a major player in a wide range of practice areas, from intellectual property to capital markets. With a special practice area devoted to patents and innovation, the firm is on the cutting edge of patent protection and litigation. Their attorneys are well positioned to advise new and emerging companies on the most recent developments in intellectual property law, particularly in the technology and life sciences sectors. If you think you’ve come up with next big thing, these are the people you want to talk to.

##3. Best Firm For Trademarking The Logo You Think Is So Cool: [Fenwick & West LLP](http://www.fenwick.com/?utm_source=ATL&utm_medium=Native%20Content&utm_campaign=FENWICK)


“The cool kids in Silicon Valley,” Fenwick openly prides itself on its geek culture, touting its involvement in headline-grabbing technology cases such as the Facebook IPO. Consistently ranked one of the best intellectual property firms on the West Coast, the firm’s attorneys are well versed in the ins and outs of trademark law. Always on the forefront of emerging technology issues, the firm has a proven track record in cases involving trademark protection and infringement. Your work is in good hands with this geek squad.

The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
##4. Best Firm For Suing The Bigger Company That Stole Your Intellectual Property: [Taylor & Company Law Offices, LLP](http://www.tcolaw.com/?utm_source=ATL&utm_medium=Native%20Content&utm_campaign=TCOLAW)


This intimate boutique firm has a reputation for providing superior business litigation services to a diverse clientele, including start-ups, software developers, and major corporations. Their intellectual property group specializes in prosecuting and defending copyright, trademark, and patent infringement cases, as well as dealing with issues of trade secret misappropriation. Spanning a wide variety of industries, the firm’s client base is made up of individuals and companies on the forefront of today’s emerging innovations, from hardware and software to biotechnology and medical devices. Your ideas are yours, and these guys will help you protect them.

##5. Best Firm For When You Actually Find Yourself In A Courtroom: [Bergeson LLP](http://www.be-law.com/?utm_source=ATL&utm_medium=Native%20Content&utm_campaign=BE-LAW)


This close-knit litigation boutique combines deep Silicon Valley roots with a reputation for being a key player in high-stakes lawsuits across a wide range of substantive areas, from intellectual property to securities fraud. Attorneys in the business litigation practice are skilled at handling every aspect of complex business disputes. The firm’s small size belies its depth of trial experience, particularly in the Northern District of California and the Santa Clara District Court. Firm founder Dan Bergeson is renowned throughout Silicon Valley for both his expertise and cost-effectiveness in all aspects of business litigation. If you need to resort to litigation, this firm will have your back.

##6. Best Firm For Keeping That Glass Ceiling Off: [Seyfarth Shaw LLP](http://www.seyfarth.com/?utm_source=ATL&utm_medium=Native%20Content&utm_campaign=SEYFARTH)


Renowned as an innovator in the field of labor and employment law, this international firm was one of the first to devote an exclusive  practice area to the field. With over 100 labor and employment attorneys in California alone, the firm offers vast expertise, including a team devoted to all aspects of pay equity-related issues. With demands for pay equality reaching a crescendo nationwide, a growing company must recognize the crucial importance of ensuring equitable pay for their employees, not merely to avoid legal risk, but to maintain competitive advantage. Seyfarth’s Pay Equity Group has over 20 years experience counseling employers on best practices to guide fair pay practices and risk mitigation, including compliance with California’s especially stringent Fair Pay Act.

##7. Best Firm For Helping You Get Office Space: [Seubert French Frimel & Warner LLP](http://sffwlaw.com/?utm_source=ATL&utm_medium=Native%20Content&utm_campaign=SSFWLAW)


Founded in the heart of Silicon Valley, this 4-lawyer boutique firm knows the ins and outs of all things real estate law. Experienced in representing both sides of real estate transactions, the firm has been a major player in some of the area’s most high-profile real estate deals. Two of the firm’s 4 name partners devote their practices to transactional and commercial real estate matters, making them the obvious choice for landlords, tenants, investors, and developers alike. When you want personalized service, this firm will deliver.

##8. Best Firm To Keep You Out Of California State Prison: Cris Arguedas of [Arguedas, Cassman & Headley](http://www.achlaw.com/index.php)


Consistently recognized as one of the best criminal defense attorneys in the country, Cris Arguedas has lent her trial skills to some of the most high-profile cases of the last 20 years. Her courtroom skills are so highly regarded that the Dream Team hired her to conduct a mock cross-examination of O.J. Simpson. While she can’t say how the test run went, we all know that O.J. didn’t testify at his trial. Arguedas is known as the lawyer that lawyers would call if they were arrested. From sensational murder trials to complex white-collar cases, Arguedas is the defense lawyer you need.

##9. Best Firm To Win The Trial Over Your Intellectual Property: [Keker & Van Nest LLP](http://www.kvn.com/?utm_source=ATL&utm_medium=Native%20Content&utm_campaign=KVN)


When it comes to protecting intellectual property and technology, this is the law firm that the world’s top innovators turn to for help. No IP dispute is too complex or novel for the firm’s lawyers, be it a question of copyright issues for a tech start-up or the patent rights for semiconductors. Name partner John Keker is widely regarded by his peers as the best trial lawyer in Silicon Valley, if not the country, thanks to four decades of success in high-profile litigation matters from some of the world’s largest corporations. When your intellectual property is on the line, this is the firm you call.

##10. Best Firm For When You Need Estate Planning After Your IPO: [Sowards Law Firm](http://www.sowardslawfirm.com/?utm_source=ATL&utm_medium=Native%20Content&utm_campaign=SOWARDSLAWFIRM)


Dedicated entirely to business law and estate planning, this boutique firm with 3 offices in Silicon Valley offers expertise in wills, trusts, and estate planning, as well as asset protection. From probate to guardianship to business succession, this firm handles it all. Serving clients that range from individuals to large corporations, the firm’s lawyers are well equipped to deal with any estate planning issues that may arise. If you’re planning for your future, they’ve got you covered.

##11. Best Firm To Advise Minority Shareholders: [Silicon Valley Law Group](http://www.svlg.com/?utm_source=ATL&utm_medium=Native%20Content&utm_campaign=SVLG)


With roots in Silicon Valley, this firm understands the unique needs and culture of the area. Well versed in the reorganizations and break-ups that happen so often in pioneering tech companies, the firm routinely handles the drafting of employment and executive compensation agreements, as well as restructurings, mergers, and acquisitions. The firm’s lawyers frequently come to the aid of minority shareholders who feel they’re being treated unfairly or are wrongfully at risk of losing control of their companies.

##12. Best Firm To Independently Advise The Board of Directors: [Kaye Scholer LLP](http://www.kayescholer.com/index?utm_source=ATL&utm_medium=Native%20Content&utm_campaign=KAYESCHOLAR)


The Silicon Valley office of this international law firm focuses on serving clients in the technology and life sciences sectors in all aspects of business law, from start-up formation to venture capital matters. Special Counsel Diane Holt Frankle regularly serves as an advisor to boards of directors on questions of fiduciary duties, internal investigations, crisis management, and corporate governance and disclosure. Capitalizing on the firm’s deep understanding of corporate law, Frankle and the firm’s other lawyers are also adept at representing companies in private and public offerings.

##13. Best Firm To Help You Making Sure You Have Capital To Keep the Lights On Until Daybreak: [King & Spalding](http://www.kslaw.com/?utm_source=ATL&utm_medium=Native%20Content&utm_campaign=KSLAW)


Renowned for their success in the corporate sector, this major international law firm has an entire practice group dedicated to emerging growth companies. With several lawyers in the Silicon Valley office, the group concentrates on helping emerging companies to get started, and then helping them grow when the time comes. Well versed in intricacies of planning and raising business capital, they are the firm to go to when your business is struggling to stay afloat or looking to expand.

##14. Best Firm For Planning (Or Avoiding) The Re-Start-Up: [Duane Morris](http://www.duanemorris.com/?utm_source=ATL&utm_medium=Native%20Content&utm_campaign=DUANEMORRIS)


For more than a century, this major international law firm has provided a vast range of legal services to clients around the world, from mergers and acquisitions to white collar criminal defense. The firm opened a Silicon Valley office in 2013 to better serve its technology sector clients. One of the office’s specialties is business reorganization and financial restructuring, drawing on the firm’s extensive bankruptcy experience to work with troubled companies to determine the best course of action and derive the maximum possible corporate value.

##15. Best Firm For To Keep You Out Of E-Discovery Hell: [Singer/Bea LLP](http://www.singerbea.com/?utm_source=ATL&utm_medium=Native%20Content&utm_campaign=SINGERBEA#about_us)


The demands of e-discovery associated with complex litigation is a potential black hole for corporate legal departments’ resources. The cutting-edge boutique Bea/Singer has you covered. This nimble and ruthlessly efficient firm of business litigation and IP ninjas has managed massive doc review and collection projects for an array of Fortune 500 companies and can leverage experience with all major e-discovery vendors. Singer/Bea clients benefit from bespoke e-discovery protocols from the get-go in order to control costs and distill the crucial evidence that will carry the day at trial.

##16. Best Firm For When You Are Ready To Get Into That Asian Market:[ Greenberg Traurig ](http://www.gtlaw.com/?utm_source=ATL&utm_medium=Native%20Content&utm_campaign=GTLAW)


For Silicon Valley companies looking to expand into Asia, Greenberg Traurig is the firm to know. With offices all over the world, including Seoul and Shanghai, the firm assists clients in nearly every area of law and in nearly every corner of the globe. In addition to advising emerging growth companies on complex corporate matters, the firm’s Silicon Valley office has developed a cutting edge international transactional practice that specifically focuses on the top Asian markets, including China, Taiwan, and Japan.

##17. Best Firm For Designing Your Employee Stock Option Plan: [Gunderson Dettmer](http://www.gunder.com/about/firm?utm_source=ATL&utm_medium=Native%20Content&utm_campaign=GUNDERLAW)


Compensation, incentive and equity plans are crucial drivers of growth for emerging companies. Gunderson’s Executive Compensation practice group develops and refines the cutting-edge plans that align with the goals of companies as they strive toward their IPO or M&A event. Gunderson offers a blend of tax, securities and regulatory know-how with an up-to-the-minute grasp of market trends and the folkways of Silicon Valley culture

##18. Best Firm For One-Horned Horsey Creatures: [Cooley LLP](https://www.cooley.com/?utm_source=ATL&utm_medium=Native%20Content&utm_campaign=COOLEY)


When it comes to making that sweet, sweet VC money fall like rain, nobody is killing larger than Cooley. The firm ranks as the number one most active firm for both early- and late-stage venture capital financings for Q1 2016, building on its status as the most active firm for VC-backed exits for all of 2015. Cooley boasts a client base of more than 5,000 emerging companies, including more than one third of The Wall Street Journal’s “Billion Dollar Startup Club.” Cooley’s commitment to innovation is exemplified by its Cooley GO program, a free resource designed to help startups blow up.

##19. Best Firm For Lobbying Congress In Your Favor: [WilmerHale](https://www.wilmerhale.com/?utm_source=ATL&utm_medium=Native%20Content&utm_campaign=WH)


Consistently recognized as one of the top lobbying shops in the country, the lawyers at WilmerHale know their way around Capitol Hill. Combined with its elite intellectual property practice, this makes the firm the ideal choice for handling the unique needs of Silicon Valley companies. For the past 10 years, the firm’s Palo Alto office has been advising companies at all levels, from venture capital start-ups to Fortune 50 corporations. When you need to see results in Washington, this is the firm you call.

##20. Best Jack-of-All-Trades Firm For High Growth Companies: [Montgomery & Hansen](http://mh-llp.com/?utm_source=ATL&utm_medium=Native%20Content&utm_campaign=MHLLP)


A firm of choice for entrepreneurs, emerging growth companies, and venture capitalists, Montgomery & Hansen has built a highly successful practice helping high-growth companies with all facets of business development, from founders agreements and executive compensation to seed and venture financings. M&H is the go-to firm for when your tiny pipedream of a company grows into a legitimate corporate enterprise. The firm’s Silicon Valley office is experienced at providing the industry-specific knowledge that emerging technology companies need to succeed.

# Following The Money? Here's Another North Star
## One dollar, two dollar, three dollar, more!
By [Chris Williams](https://abovethelaw.com/author/cwilliams/)  
onFebruary 25, 2022 at 10:33 AMFebruary 25, 2022 at 10:21 AM
5
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/02/vinson-raise-2022/&text=Following%20The%20Money?%20Here’s%20Another%20North%20Star)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/02/vinson-raise-2022/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/02/vinson-raise-2022/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Saying thanks is nice and all, but appreciation doesn’t keep the lights on. That’s why when big firms want to really show support, they send it to the bank.

Vinson & Elkins just said thank you in a major way, joining the new Davis Polk scale. And as the 72nd highest grossing law firm in the world according to Am Law’s 2021 Global 200 survey, they’ve got a lot to share. Here’s the breakdown.

Class Year	Annual Base Salary
2021	$215,000
2020	$225,000
2019	$250,000
2018	$293,500
2017	$335,000
2016	$360,500
2015	$381,000
  2014+	$396,500
The raises will be retroactive to January 1 and will hit bank accounts in March. Woop Woop!

(Turn to the next page to see the Vinson & Elkins memo.)

[*** Wondering if the grass is greener on the in-house side? Click here for a look inside the black box of corporate counsel pay in our 2021 In-House Compensation Report. ***](https://info.abovethelaw.com/2021-in-house-compensation-survey-report)

We like hearing about salary increases almost as much as you enjoy spending them. As soon as your firm’s memo comes out, please [email it to us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches”) or text us (646-820-8477). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Salary & Bonus Alerts, please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish.

Chris Williams became a social media manager and assistant editor for Above the Law in June 2021. Prior to joining the staff, he moonlighted as a minor Memelord™ in the Facebook group [Law School Memes for Edgy T14s](https://www.facebook.com/photo/?fbid=10222912314148913&set=p.10222912314148913&opaqueCursor=AboVBPzRKh4loie1LupyI7ltSvsaUWxURlMk_338xXb_BPhzMNPHbWfVDUsOyUH1mfvHQ4Bsipef989J-V0OyqhMZzHPafTw49vttxDh_no8xymRSSUssmh47qTzHAc13R0wzk8nPhgSylnSAYcBNbHjYDqZDqy5r0f7PwzCZw9T-0cakKMIin3XI0O8R5H5OJGAu4kJjGPAoZpgL6woU9lwoHiAjxAwAlpmdlyt6vHLJ1TVn2srkC3G4qBW5ANthJ_YNT3BUPCu2vu1ZIxiqYwXGLfMIxQR4cllUaB0Cja74ln1FHs3n-xyHe6MDtxln0-F4QJchox9nCaivB_xmSxw3FduERhPebhWj1MKJ20jeucGZ64jY6DdUn2d87dVgNlFE5qHvNEtfMpoEKx1096oFfqbZ9s71YVsbXxLIsRiiW54eLp4R7z3WHAKu8v8xeLIZt86UVU1iOaSlJ0n5tT3_VonQT6n2F0sIUSLY272cI-yjWxaUIr0Qj-1NQDFFcn9dkq8pYV2-o0M3LK2Qhr9LKt-Bk4MTGUZCkb4Kw6mgDmRCux3nhJqd2hdLd8LgTA).  He endured Missouri long enough to graduate from Washington University in St. Louis School of Law. He is a former boatbuilder who cannot swim, [a published author on critical race theory, philosophy, and humor](https://www.academia.edu/33296970/Lets_Be_Frank_Parrhesia_and_the_Black_Comedic_Tradition), and has a love for cycling that occasionally annoys his peers. You can reach him by email at [cwilliams@abovethelaw.com](mailto:cwilliams@abovethelaw.com) and by tweet at [@WritesForRent](https://twitter.com/WritesForRent).

# After Holding The Line Against Donald Trump, Jeffrey Rosen Heads To Biglaw
## He's used to difficult clients.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onJuly 17, 2023 at 5:44 PMJuly 17, 2023 at 5:21 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/07/after-holding-the-line-against-donald-trump-jeffrey-rosen-heads-to-biglaw/&text=After%20Holding%20The%20Line%20Against%20Donald%20Trump,%20Jeffrey%20Rosen%20Heads%20To%20Biglaw)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/07/after-holding-the-line-against-donald-trump-jeffrey-rosen-heads-to-biglaw/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/07/after-holding-the-line-against-donald-trump-jeffrey-rosen-heads-to-biglaw/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

# Firm's Complex Bonus Structure Provides Most Associates With Less Than Their Peers
## Not every firm can pay like Cravath.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onDecember 18, 2017 at 10:44 AMDecember 18, 2017 at 10:26 AM
10
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2017/12/firms-complex-bonus-structure-providing-most-associates-with-less-than-their-peers/&text=Firm’s%20Complex%20Bonus%20Structure%20Provides%20Most%20Associates%20With%20Less%20Than%20Their%20Peers)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2017/12/firms-complex-bonus-structure-providing-most-associates-with-less-than-their-peers/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2017/12/firms-complex-bonus-structure-providing-most-associates-with-less-than-their-peers/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
When we discuss the emerging break between the [haves and have nots](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/12/2018-looks-like-another-year-of-blah-for-the-legal-industry/) among the Am Law 100, Bryan Cave is the sort of firm on the wrong side of that divide. The industry is pulling work from most of the top firms in favor of smaller shops or handling more in-house while simultaneously doubling down on the truly elite firms creating a tier of top Biglaw firms that seem stuck in neutral. Dig a little deeper on Bryan Cave and there’s a firm that’s suffered declines in gross revenue for three straight years, making it a poster child for this phenomenon sweeping the Am Law 100.

So it’s probably unsurprising that Bryan Cave’s bonuses don’t reach the heights that Cravath can afford. The firm’s bonus memo is now out and it’s eschewing the standard class year formula for a matrix of two class year tiers and billable hours that leave most associates compensated well-below their peers at other firms.

For the sake of clarity, here are the bonus ranges associates can reach based on where their billable hours are on a range of 1900-2300.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Class of 2016 — $10K-30K
Class of 2015 — $10K-30K
Class of 2014 — $15K-45K
Class of 2013 — $15K-45K
Class of 2012 & Earlier — $20K-60K

So to put this in perspective, a 2016 grad billing 2000 hours would receive $15,000 which would put them perfectly in line with their peers. And a 2016 grad billing 2300 hours can bring home $30,000, which is a sizable advantage over most firms.

But the 2015 grad faces another reality. A 2015 grad billing a standard 2000 hours would receive $15,000, while the same lawyer on the Cravath scale would bring home $25,000. The class of 2015 Bryan Cave lawyer would need to bill 2200 hours before they reached the Cravath par.

And it gets more bleak as we move up the scale, with associates in the class of 2014 and earlier unable to approach the Cravath scale no matter how many hours they bill.
